awd_titl_txt: Supporting Science Teaching: The San Diego State University Noyce Scholars and Interns Program
awd_abstract_narration:
With funding from the National Science Foundation's Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program, this San Diego State University (SDSU) Noyce Scholarship Track I project will address the national need to produce a high quality teaching workforce in science. The project will recruit a select group of high-achieving and diverse science majors into teaching and will provide support through a variety of hands-on, research-based learning experiences to develop the recipients' teaching practices and science content knowledge, while nurturing their enthusiasm for teaching. The project will provide financial support for seventy-four (74) internships and scholarships, and work with SDSU's existing Center for the Advancement of Students in Academia (CASA) to give particular attention to recruiting participants from diverse backgrounds, including students from underrepresented minorities. Results from the project not only will enhance science workforce diversity, but will also contribute to a broader understanding of how teacher preparation programs can be tailored to reach and prepare underrepresented students for successful science teaching careers. 
 
The program will offer forty (40) Noyce Internships to first and second year biology, chemistry, geology, and physics majors, who will explore teaching through participating in SDSU's summer camp for students from grades 2-8. The camp will be set in place through this grant, and will be sustained by SDSU once the grant is completed. Select interns and other science majors will receive scholarships to become Noyce Scholars during their teaching credential year and as new teachers placed in high needs schools. The program will produce at least thirty-four (34) new high quality science teachers through these scholarships, and the investigators will help place graduates from the program in high needs schools and then provide them with important and timely support when they enter the STEM teaching profession. The project will build on SDSU's Noyce Master Teacher Fellows project (NSF #1240127) by placing the Noyce Scholars from this project in classrooms of master teachers from the Teacher Fellows program. These experienced Teacher Fellows will serve as guides and mentors for the new Teaching Scholars. The overall project will be housed in SDSU's Center for Research in Mathematics and Science Education, and the research and evaluation plans include methodologies for measuring the role of the Noyce Internships in providing early opportunities to promote teaching as a career and for measuring the effectiveness of the Noyce scholarship recipients as teachers.

por.por_cntn:
Supporting Science Teaching: The San Diego State University (SDSU) Noyce Scholars and Interns Program developed 41 specially selected science majors to become secondary science teachers who teach in diverse communities in San Diego County. These Scholars were chosen through a rigorous application and interview process. We far exceeded the total number of interns and Scholarships that we proposed to provide. In our submission, we proposed to hire 40 interns and to award 34 Scholarships.  Over the life of the grant, we hired 53 interns (69 if we include those paid from other sources), and awarded 41 Scholarships of $10,000 each. We awarded 20% more scholarships than proposed.

Scope of Impact

Local Educational Community

  • The majority of SDSU's Scholars are teaching in high-need schools in San Diego County, and collectively they have the potential to influence the lives of tens of thousands of students. The Scholars have already made, and will continue to make, a difference to an ever-growing circle of teachers and their students.
  • During the grant, the percentage of science credential earners at SDSU increased an average of 73% when compared with the 3 years prior to the grant. We attribute much of this increase to the enhanced visibility of the program, the options provided within the credential program, and to the variety of recruitment efforts into teaching.
  • In addition to growing the number of students in the credential program, the diversity of the students in the program also grew. In particular, the number of teachers who identify as Asian increased 350% and the number of teachers who identify as belonging to two or more ethnic or racial groups grew 86%.
  • A Scholar from SDSU shared a video that was widely disseminated during Teacher Appreciation Week. In addition, the video was sent to the entire NSF Division of Undergraduate Education. To view his video, click the link: 

https://players.brightcove.net/679256133001/NkgrDczuol_default/index.html?videoId=6253507064001

Program Sustainability

  • This program will have ongoing impact on teachers and students in the region because the Scholars who became secondary science teachers will continue to serve their own students, and we are confident that they will influence the teaching practices of colleagues and other school personnel across the region. Importantly, these Scholars will continue to serve as thoughtful and effective teachers for years to come.
  • We developed a new course as a Field Experience course specifically for science majors to explore their fitness for science teaching. The course is called, TE 462, Field Experience in Science Classrooms, and is now established as a course focused on science teaching for our Interns and other chemistry, physics, and biology majors. The development and approval of this course is a sign of the commitment of SDSU to continue to offer this course long after the grant has ended.
  • We developed a specialized Science and Mathematics Credential Cohort. The explicit focus of this cohort on STEM teaching has been an attractive option to our prospective STEM teachers, and this focus has provided opportunities for students to think deeply about what it means to teach science and mathematics in an inquiry-oriented way. This cohort will continue running long after the grant has ended.
  • We developed recruitment practices into science teaching that will continue long after the grant ends. Because we can share information about the course TE 462 and the Mathematics and Science cohort, we have opportunities to share how STEM majors can explore teaching.

Last Modified: 10/12/2021
Modified by: Lisa L Lamb

Images (1 of )
  • SDSU's Noyce Scholars attend a CA Science Teacher Conference in 2019.
    Donna Ross
    Public Domain
    Lisa L Lamb
    Noyce Scholars at Science Conference
  • SDSU's Noyce Scholars attended the Noyce Western Regional Conference in February 2020, just weeks before the shutdown due to COVID-19.
    Susan Nickerson
    Public Domain
    Lisa L Lamb
    Noyce Scholars at NWRC 2020
por.por_txt_cntn:
Supporting Science Teaching: The San Diego State University (SDSU) Noyce Scholars and Interns Program developed 41 specially selected science majors to become secondary science teachers who teach in diverse communities in San Diego County. These Scholars were chosen through a rigorous application and interview process. We far exceeded the total number of interns and Scholarships that we proposed to provide. In our submission, we proposed to hire 40 interns and to award 34 Scholarships.  Over the life of the grant, we hired 53 interns (69 if we include those paid from other sources), and awarded 41 Scholarships of $10,000 each. We awarded 20% more scholarships than proposed.
Scope of Impact
Local Educational Community

The majority of SDSU's Scholars are teaching in high-need schools in San Diego County, and collectively they have the potential to influence the lives of tens of thousands of students. The Scholars have already made, and will continue to make, a difference to an ever-growing circle of teachers and their students. 
During the grant, the percentage of science credential earners at SDSU increased an average of 73% when compared with the 3 years prior to the grant. We attribute much of this increase to the enhanced visibility of the program, the options provided within the credential program, and to the variety of recruitment efforts into teaching. 
In addition to growing the number of students in the credential program, the diversity of the students in the program also grew. In particular, the number of teachers who identify as Asian increased 350% and the number of teachers who identify as belonging to two or more ethnic or racial groups grew 86%. 
A Scholar from SDSU shared a video that was widely disseminated during Teacher Appreciation Week. In addition, the video was sent to the entire NSF Division of Undergraduate Education. To view his video, click the link: 


https://players.brightcove.net/679256133001/NkgrDczuol_default/index.html?videoId=6253507064001

Program Sustainability

This program will have ongoing impact on teachers and students in the region because the Scholars who became secondary science teachers will continue to serve their own students, and we are confident that they will influence the teaching practices of colleagues and other school personnel across the region. Importantly, these Scholars will continue to serve as thoughtful and effective teachers for years to come.
We developed a new course as a Field Experience course specifically for science majors to explore their fitness for science teaching. The course is called, TE 462, Field Experience in Science Classrooms, and is now established as a course focused on science teaching for our Interns and other chemistry, physics, and biology majors. The development and approval of this course is a sign of the commitment of SDSU to continue to offer this course long after the grant has ended. 
We developed a specialized Science and Mathematics Credential Cohort. The explicit focus of this cohort on STEM teaching has been an attractive option to our prospective STEM teachers, and this focus has provided opportunities for students to think deeply about what it means to teach science and mathematics in an inquiry-oriented way. This cohort will continue running long after the grant has ended. 
We developed recruitment practices into science teaching that will continue long after the grant ends. Because we can share information about the course TE 462 and the Mathematics and Science cohort, we have opportunities to share how STEM majors can explore teaching.

					Submitted by: Lisa L Lamb
